Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: The Effect of Plant Dispersal on Ecosystem Function
Award.AbstractNarration:
Plant communities are the main source of energy for the rest of life. Habitat loss and fragmentation -- the conversion of large areas into isolated smaller areas -- threaten the diversity of plant communities and ecosystem functions (essential services provided by plants). Thus, it important that we understand how to maintain plant communities and how they help ecosystems function. This project explores how seed dispersal in fragmented habitats helps sustain plant diversity and promote ecosystem functions such as nutrient cycles and decomposition rates. Investigators will examine whether habitat fragmentation has an unusually large impact on the abundance of plant species that are poor seed dispersers and, if so, how loss of these species may result in loss of ecosystem function. Scientists working on this project will engage with the public through talks, a workshop, and internship opportunities. Results will help inform the U.S. Army Corp of Engineers and their mission of conservation.

Investigators will study impacts of habitat fragmentation on plant communities and ecosystem functions, using a set of islands in Lake Strom Thurmond, South Carolina. Plant communities, plant chemical and physical attributes, and soil properties will be measured on 20 islands of different levels of spatial isolation (near shore versus far from shore) and historic disturbance. Specifically, investigators will quantify the abundance and diversity of plant species, leaf properties of those species, soil nitrogen availability, and microbial decomposition rates. These data will be used to test the hypothesis that spatial isolation and disturbance affect ecosystem function by altering plant species composition. Statistical models will test 1) whether ecosystem carbon and nutrient fluxes are a function of spatial isolation, disturbance history, and leaf properties; and 2) whether dispersal limitation caused by island spatial isolation can drive functional composition.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ecosystems drive the key processes that sustain life on Earth. Plants are one of the key drivers of ecosystem processes such as energy and nutrient cycling because plants are the primary source of energy for the rest of life and make up most of the biomass on Earth. Plant species contribute to ecosystem processes through a unique combination of physical and chemical characteristics known as functional traits, making it important to understand what plants grow where they do and why. The primary aim of this research was to shed light on the factors that affect how plants drive ecosystem processes, generating important advances in our understanding of ecology.

The physical environment is often assumed to be the primary factor affecting why particular plants are found growing where they do. However, a key assumption is that all species’ seeds must have first had the chance to reach all potential habitats. All seeds actually do not always get to all habitats. This inherent limitation of seeds getting around is called dispersal limitation and the scope of this research was to understand the importance of dispersal limitation as a driver of long-term community dynamics and ecosystem processes.

Species differ in the characteristics that determine how easily their seeds get around. For example, a plant such as a dandelion which produces seeds that easily fly in the wind long distances is predicted to be less dispersal limited than a plant which produces seeds that immediately fall to the ground. Differences in dispersal limitation can then interact with differences in the spatial isolation of habitats to generate communities composed of species largely based on dispersal rather than environment alone. Theories about tradeoffs in resource allocation suggest that species with particular dispersal abilities should also have particular associated functional traits. This means that isolated habitats are also predicted to be biased with respect to the functional traits in those communities—which has direct potential consequences for the ecosystems of those habitats.

The current research tested the effect of dispersal limitation on ecosystem function by using the dispersal limited habitats of isolated islands. Specifically, we surveyed the trees and shrubs and ecosystem properties of islands in Clarks Hill Lake, Georgia—a reservoir that was built in the 1950s. The islands in this lake fall across a gradient of spatial isolation and some were logged at the time of lake formation, providing an ideal study system for testing whether dispersal limitation can affect plant community dynamics and subsequent ecosystem processes.

Twenty islands were surveyed beginning in Fall 2016 through Summer 2017. The abundance of each tree and shrub was recorded and soil samples were collected to measure the ecosystem properties of each island. Leaf samples were also collected to test the link between plant functional traits and their effect on ecosystems. We found that island isolation had substantial effects on the relative abundance of tree species on these islands, considerably reducing the abundance of one dominant tree species in particular (loblolly pine). This finding supports the role of dispersal limitation as a significant driver of long-term forest succession and community development. While controlling for other covariates we also found that several key functional traits significantly varied with island isolation. Ecosystem properties such as soil organic matter quality and nitrogen cycling similarly varied with island isolation, suggesting that dispersal limitation can have long-term legacy effects on ecosystem processes. Altogether, the results of this study provide strong evidence for the importance of plant dispersal as a key driver of ecosystem processes.

Overall, this research provides key advances in the field of ecology by finding that plant dispersal can be a significant driver of long-term plant community dynamics and ecosystem processes. Previous work testing the role of dispersal has largely focused on and been limited to short-term experimental and theoretical studies. This work also provided the training and experiential learning opportunity for two recent undergraduate assistants in the field and lab. One assistant was from New York State while the other was from Louisiana. During the fieldwork in Georgia we had the opportunity to collaborate with the local Army Corp of Engineers where I will be sending all data, reports, and findings for them to make available as educational material for the general public. We will also be sending lists of all plant species recorded for each island to the local Boy Scout troop for them to use as an educational resource in their outings.
